results.title: The Salt marsh: a question of values
results.creator_credit: Stanley Croner and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: For the survival of humanity, we have to recognise the limits of our exploitation of natural systems. This film documents the value of the botanical communities that exist between sea and land. Emphasises the importance of energy flow and food supply in marshes and estuaries.

results.title: The Salmon industry of British Columbia
results.brief_description: The film opens with a map of the fishing grounds of the world, and the waters of British Columbia are selected to show details of the large-scale salmon industry. A study of this extremely active and resourceful fish in its natural surroundings is always fascinating, and this film combines a clear exposition of fishing by seine net, and the preparation of the fish for the cannery.

results.title: The Salmon
results.creator_credit: Maxwell Munden and Max Munden Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Anglers’ Corner”.
A summary of the salmon’s birth, run to the sea, and return, after a year or more to the river of its birth, is given, and we see the various stages described with underwater photography. A local angler shows the technique of catching the salmon by the fly fishing method in a river in Westmoreland.

results.title: The Salesman isn't dead, he's different
results.brief_description: Presents selling as a career. Points out the values and objectives of selling from view points of the men in the field and management. Shows the metamorphosis of the salesman from the slick talkers of half a century ago to the sophisticated account representative of today. Gives examples of what the successful modern salesman does, how he does it and his secondary responsibilities and benefits.

results.title: The Sailor's return
results.creator_credit: Jack Gold, Otto Plaschkes, Ariel Productions and Euston Films
results.brief_description:
Set in the mid-19th century, this is the story of a sailor who returns to England with a black bride, an African princess, and sets up business as an innkeeper with her dowry. Before long they encounter racial prejudice from family and neighbours, which quickly reaches hysterical proportions with tragic results. Although the film features a strong performance from Tom Bell and an impressive re-creation of ‘unspoiled’ English village life, its treatment of racism is naive and confused, lacking historical context, especially in relation to the British imperialism that shaped British society in the 19th century.

Credits:Producer, Otto Plaschkes ; director, Jack Gold ; writer, James Saunders ; photography, Brian Trufano ; editing, Michael Taylor ; music, Carl Davis.
Cast: Tom Bell, Shope Shodeinde, Mick Ford, Paola Dionisotti, George Costigan.

results.title: The Safety supervisor
results.creator_credit: Ronald Weyman, Michael Spencer and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: This film presents the problems confronting the safety supervisor in relation to both management and labor. It cites the case of Mr Gilchrist who found himself at loggerheads with management over apparent indifference toward safety protection, and with labor because of frequent negligence. The camera accompanies Mr Gilchrist and the manager on an inspection tour of the plant and records their observations on a number of typical accident hazards. As a result of a bandaged head acquired on the tour, Mr Gilchrist is able to reiterate with renewed emphasis the need for adequate safety measures.

results.title: The Saddlemaker
results.creator_credit: Grant Crabtree, Tim Wilson and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: From Alberta’s cowboy country, a story of a young girl’s first love, a saddle. Every saddle that leaves Felmer Eamor’s shop becomes a proud possession. In this film you sympathise with a fourteen-year-old girl’s wish to have such a saddle, and the bluff she pulls to get it.

results.title: The Saddle Club: horse crazy
results.creator_credit: Chris Martin-Jones, Mandy Smith, Steve Mann, Lynn Bayonas, Crawfords Australia and Protocol Entertainment
results.brief_description: An Australian/Canadian co-production, based on the best selling children and young adult series ‘The Saddle Club’ and ‘Pine Hollow’ written by Bonnie Bryant. Studious Lisa (Lara Jean Marshall), tomboy Stevie (Sophie Bennett) and horse-crazy Carole (Keenan Macwilliam) are the Saddle Club, best friends united by their love for horses and their willingness to help each other. A film crew use Pine Hollow as a location and rivalry stirs as the girls audition for a part. Can the leading man really ride a horse though? The girls in the club decide to help out so he doesn’t hurt ‘Comanche’. The dodgy wiring at Pine Hollow sends sparks into Max’s love life and the girls help him out with a makeover for his first date. The girls also get some fun-time too as they take part in a Rodeo weekend.

results.title: The Saddle Club: friends forever
results.creator_credit: Arnie Custo, Mark De Friest, Lynn Bayonas, Crawfords Australia and Protocol Entertainment
results.brief_description: An Australian/Canadian co-production, based on the best selling children and young adult series ‘The Saddle Club’ and ‘Pine Hollow’ written by Bonnie Bryant. Studious Lisa (Lara Jean Marshall), tomboy Stevie (Sophie Bennett) and horse-crazy Carole (Keenan Macwilliam) are the Saddle Club, best friends united by their love for horses and their willingness to help each other. The arrival of the beautiful French Junior Champion, Dorothee Doutey (Matylda Buezko) creates a stir at Pine Hollow. What is her mystery behind her ‘rest’ and her disconnection from her horse ‘Hugo’? While the club try to remedy the situation another serious dilemma surfaces in the form of an unknown horse virus that threatens the stables. The club rally again to race against possible disaster. Will Dorothee take up her Olympic selection or settle on love with one of the stablehands? The girls also get to do their first singing performance in front of an audience.

results.title: The Saddle Club: adventures at Pine Hollow [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Chris Martin-Jones, Peter Sharp, Steve Mann, Lynn Bayonas, Crawfords Australia and Protocol Entertainment
results.brief_description: An Australian/Canadian co-production, based on the best selling children and young adult series ‘The Saddle Club’ and ‘Pine Hollow’ written by Bonnie Bryant. Studious Lisa (Lara Jean Marshall), tomboy Stevie (Sophie Bennett) and horse-crazy Carole (Keenan Macwilliam) are the Saddle Club, best friends united by their love for horses and their willingness to help each other. Carole is offered the opportunity to be part of a work study program with the local vet, and is thrilled. Not only is being a vet her dream, but she can work with cute animals all day. Things don’t turn out as well as she plans and her confidence in her abilities drops. When spoilt rich-girl Veronica di Angelo’s negligence results in her horse Cobalt being put down, Carole is devastated and quits riding completely. Lisa and Stevie must work together to change their friend’s mind. They’ve already lost Cobalt, they don’t want to lose Carole too. Between riding, school and the dramas of pre-adolescence, the impending birth of a foal makes sure life at Pine Hollow is as chaotic as usual. Also available on VHS [315648].
